entry.title: Session 1 Recap & Highlight - SAP BDC The Future of Intelligent Data Architectures üöÄ
entry.content:
Why SAP Invested in BDC üí°

The journey started with SAP‚Äôs recognition of a growing "context gap" in enterprise data‚Äîwhich emerges when organizations must stitch together SAP and non-SAP data across disparate platforms (think Databricks, Snowflake, Microsoft Fabric). Without business context, analytics and AI initiatives often struggle to deliver real value. BDC was built to close this gap by harmonizing and managing all enterprise data‚Äîstructured, semi-structured, SAP, and non-SAP‚Äîin a unified, semantically enriched way.

 

What Sets BDC Apart? üéØ

  • Automation First: BDC flips the script on traditional data management, automating data curation and harmonization. Instead of endless upfront effort, customers get ready-to-consume, semantically rich data products‚Äîsaving time and reducing what SAP calls the ‚Äúhidden data tax‚Äù.
  • Data Product Model: SAP identifies ‚Äúprimary data products‚Äù (like finance, supply chain, HR) and brings them directly from SAP applications into BDC, curated and cataloged for instant use. The goal is to reach 500 data products by year-end‚Äîcovering virtually every major enterprise domain.
  • AI-Ready Fabric: BDC‚Äôs lakehouse architecture and built-in ‚Äúbusiness fabric‚Äù layer empower businesses to use advanced analytics, natural language queries, and AI seamlessly. Dual integration and knowledge graph support mean both applications and users can access harmonized, context-rich insights.

 

Interoperability & Ecosystem üåê

  • BDC Connect: This technology helps integrate BDC with non-SAP systems like Databricks, enabling zero-copy data sharing and harmonized catalogs‚Äîperfect for hybrid and multicloud enterprises.
  • Marketplace Vision: SAP is launching a data products marketplace, encouraging partners and customers to publish, consume, and innovate with SAP and non-SAP data. The upcoming announcement at SAP Connect will explain how the ecosystem and intelligent apps can grow‚Äîmost delivered by partners, not just SAP.

 

Data Democratization: Empowering Every Employee üë•

Pinar described SAP‚Äôs internal rollout‚Äî‚Äúcustomer zero‚Äù‚Äîwhere business users, not just IT, access BDC‚Äôs data products and build dashboards in hours. This isn‚Äôt just technology; SAP orchestrates enablement cohorts, training citizen analysts to maximize value and foster data-driven decision making at every level.

  • Reusable Data Products: Designed for broad, multi-use case consumption, not one-off analytics. Both IT and business users (citizen analysts) can build, extend, and share data-driven solutions thanks to low-code/no-code tooling.
  • Enablement & Governance: SAP couples technology with strong governance and enablement programs‚Äîusing Collibra for cataloging, trust-building, and making metadata as easy to navigate as grocery shopping.

 

 

üåçWhether you‚Äôre an enterprise architect, citizen analyst, or just curious about the future of business intelligence‚ÄîSAP Business Data Cloud delivers a new foundation for turning data into real business outcomes, faster and smarter than ever before.

üôã‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è Which BDC feature excites you most? Are you ready for data democratization in your organization? Share your thoughts below!

Note: Slides from the session and the recording would be only available to the registered attendees. So if you have not registered, please register now using the link below:

https://events.sap.com/eaa-bdc-apac/en_us/home.html#accordion-5d79451476-item-9ff3b2b36e

 

Important links üîó

  1. Architecture Center: https://architecture.learning.sap.com/
  2. Enterprise Architect Learning Journey: https://learning.sap.com/learning-journeys/discovering-sap-enterprise-architecture
  3. SAP Business Data Cloud Learning Journey: https://learning.sap.com/courses/introducing-sap-business-data-cloud

entry.title: Balance Validation accelerating the period closing by Superb validation, automation and analytics
entry.content:
Join us for co-innovation

We would like to invite the public cloud customers joining us for the co-innovation of AI capability AI assisted Balance Validation Rule Creation, and if you are with valid FBA, please feel free to reply me in this blog, and we are looking forward meeting you.

Let's shape the future together. 

Challenge

Organizations often face challenges such as a financial close process that struggles to reach peak performance, characterized by inefficiencies and delayed timelines. Additionally, governance and compliance requirements can become overly burdensome, consuming valuable time with extensive data collection and documentation efforts. Furthermore, there is frequently a lack of transparency and insight across system boundaries, which hampers decision-making and collaboration. Tackling these issues requires a strategic approach that involves process optimization, technology adoption, and fostering a culture of collaboration and continuous improvement.

Key capabilities in financial management systems are designed to enhance accuracy, efficiency, and communication.

  • Managing validation rules and groups standardizes these processes, preventing financial misstatements and reducing audit and compliance risks.
  • Automated balance validation tasks accelerate the closing process and minimize manual efforts, freeing up valuable time for strategic activities.
  • Real-time validation analytics provide immediate insights and maintain a comprehensive audit trail, ensuring transparency and accountability.
  • The ability to add comments facilitates smooth communication between subsidiaries and headquarters, ensuring alignment and reducing misunderstandings. Together, these capabilities transform financial operations, driving reliability and efficiency.

Balance Validation plays a critical role in supporting Accounting and Group Reporting, especially when integrated with Advanced Financial Closing processes. This function ensures that all accounts are accurately reconciled and validated, providing a strong foundation for precise financial reporting. By incorporating Balance Validation into the closing cycle, organizations can identify discrepancies early, reduce errors, and enhance the integrity of their financial statements. This integration not only accelerates the closing process but also strengthens group reporting by ensuring consistent and reliable data across all levels of the organization, thereby supporting compliance and informed strategic decision-making.

The application of Manage Balance Validation Rules and Groups provides a centralized platform for defining and managing validation rules that prevent financial misstatements and mitigate compliance risks. 

The application Scheduled Balance Validation Jobs accelerates the financial closing cycle while significantly reducing manual workload by automating balance validation tasks. 

The application View Balance Validation Results offers immediate insights and maintains an audit trail, ensuring transparency. Furthermore, it facilitates seamless communication between subsidiaries and headquarters, ensuring alignment and effective coordination across all financial activities.

Roadmap

We will provide AI assisted Balance Validation Rule Creation on S/4HANA Public Cloud to empower business users by simplifying the rule definition process, enhancing flexibility, and improving responsiveness to customer-specific requirements, reducing the dependency on business process experts.

Users initiate requests using straightforward business language. The AI then analyzes historical data and industry best practices to draft a proposed validation rule, incorporating common elements such as G/L account hierarchy nodes and function areas. This intelligent proposal streamlines the rule creation process, minimizing the need for specialized expertise. Users can subsequently review the draft, make necessary adjustments, and save or activate the rule, ensuring it aligns with organizational requirements and enhances the accuracy and efficiency of financial operations.


 

 

Here is the help document about Balance Validation capability,

Balance Validation | SAP Help Portal

entry.title: Re: Moving stock from blocked to Other storage location n...
entry.content:
Greetings,

please observe customizing for 322 movemnt type and 343. I performed a test for movemnt type 322 which triggered an inspection lot. I tried the same from 343 but this inspection lot was not created.

I checked the movemnt type customizing and inspection lot origin is not assigned to movemnt type 343. I copied movemnt type 322 to 343 in hopes that the filed will be populated but SAP deletes it at save.

Movemnt type 322 has this field populated and SAP documentation states "The inspection lot origin for a movement type is to  defined by SAP and cannot be changed." Perhaps your only option is to create a Z movement type

Best regards, M.

entry.title: How to configure SAML SSO for SAP HANA Cockpit -with Database Groups&Resource Ids as SAML Attributes
entry.content:
Prerequisites:

  • SAP HANA Cockpit has been installed and running.
  • An administration account in SAP HANA Cockpit is available, i.e. COCKPIT_ADMIN.
  • Identity Provider service application is available for use. 

Procedures:

Section 1. Preparation in HANA Cockpit Manager

In this section, you may consider creating or assigning expected database groups and registered database resources for IdP users.

  1. Open HANA Cockpit Manager with an administration user, i.e. COCKPIT_ADMIN or XSA_ADMIN, navigate to ‚ÄúDatabase Groups‚Äù.

  2. Create database groups and assign Databases to the group.



  3. Note down the Resource IDs (ResID) of the Databases that the IdP user is expected to access.
    Go to Registered Databases ‚Äì Select the Database resource and find the ResID at the end of the URL.


    In above screenshot, ResID = 49623.

     

Section 2. (Optional) Configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Service Part I - User setup

  1. Note: If the user is expected to access all database groups, then you can skip this section.
    Configure user attributes
    1. In SAP IDS, click Menu Tab ‚ÄúUsers & Authorizations‚Äù ‚Äì select ‚ÄúUser Management‚Äù



    2. Search for the IdP user account, click to open the user configuration.
      Verify whether there‚Äôs correct email address maintained.
    3. Expend the drop-down of ‚ÄúDetails‚Äù, click to navigate to ‚ÄúCustom Attributes‚Äù

    4. Enter the Database Group Name of this user in ‚ÄúCustom Attribute 1‚Äù. E.g. SYSTEMDBs



    5. To specify Database Resources, enter the ResID (resource ID) of each database resources, delimited by comma in ‚ÄúCustom Attribute 2‚Äù.  The ResID can be found in the way introduced in Section 1 ‚Äì Step 3.

      For example, 49623 for SYSTEMDB@H78.

      • If multiple database groups or resources need to be mapped, use comma-separated list without spaces.



      • If the user expects to enter all Database Resources under this Database Group, leave the ‚ÄúCustom Attribute 2‚Äù as blank.

Section 3. Configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Service Part II ‚Äì Setup Groups and Download Metadata

In this documentation, we use SAP Cloud Identity Service (SAP IDS) as Identity Provider, you can also use other IdP alternatively.

  1. Groups Setup
    1. Access SAP Cloud Identity Service, create ‚ÄúGroups‚Äù under ‚ÄúUsers & Authorizations‚Äù.


      Create below Groups.
      • HANA_COCKPIT_USER
      • IDP_USER
      • HANA_COCKPIT_ADMIN
      • HANA_COCKPIT_RESOURCE_ADMIN
      • HANA_COCKPIT_USER_ADMIN
      • HANA_COCKPIT_POWER_USER





    2. After creating the Groups, your account can be seen as a member of the group.



      As administrator, the authorizations of the IDP user can be controlled by assigning different groups to the user.
      You can access User Management, search for the user ID, and open the Groups tab.

      *The creation (and mapping) of Groups depends on the corresponding Role collections that the IDP user expects.





      For example, a user is able to access HANA Cockpit with specific Database Group or Resources with below Groups assigned.
      • HANA_COCKPIT_USER
      • IDP_USER

  2. Download the metadata of the Identity Provider service.
    1. Go to ‚ÄúApplications & Resources‚Äù ‚Äì ‚ÄúTenant Settings‚Äù



    2. Select ‚ÄúSingle Sign-On‚Äù ‚Äì ‚ÄúSAML 2.0 Configuration‚Äù



    3. Click ‚ÄúDownload Metadata File‚Äù and save the Metadata File to local.

Section 4. Configuration in XSA Cockpit

  1. Open the XSA Cockpit in web browser.
    The url can either be found from the API URL:




    Or it can be found from the xs apps list:



    Login as an administration account, e.g. COCKPIT_ADMIN or XSA_ADMIN.

  2. (Optional) Create IDP Role, Role Collection and Role Mappings
    Note: If there‚Äôs no requirement for IDP user to access HANA Cockpit with specific Database Groups and Resources, then you can pass this step.
    1. Navigate to left menu bar Security ‚Äì Role Collections ‚Äì New Role Collection
      Name: IDP_USER



      Currently, there‚Äôs no Role assigned to it.

    2. Navigate to left menu bar Organizations ‚Äì E.g. HANACockpit ‚Äì the Space where Cockpit installed, E.g. SAP, find Application cockpit-persistence-svc, click to open the configuration of this Application.



    3. Navigate the left menu bar Security ‚Äì Roles, create a new Role.



      Name: IDP_USER
      Template: COCKPIT_IDP_USER
      Attributes:
      ResourceGroups  - Identity Provider (SAML) ‚Äì ResourceGroups
      Resources - Identity Provider (SAML) ‚Äì Resources



      Save.

    4.  

      Assign this Role to the Role Collection
      You can see the Role IDP_USER just collected, click the ‚Äú+‚Äù button.



      Select IDP_USER Role Collection which we created in Step 2.a.  And Save.



  3. Create IdP Trust Configuration
    1. Go to the Home page of XSA Cockpit, e.g. Click ‚ÄúHome‚Äù.



    2. Navigate to left menu bar ‚ÄúSecurity‚Äù ‚Äì ‚ÄúIdP Trust Configuration‚Äù ‚Äì Click ‚ÄúNew Trust Configuration‚Äù



    3. Click the ‚ÄúUpload‚Äù button and upload the IdP Metadata xml file downloaded in Section 3 ‚Äì Step 2.c.


      No need for other modification at this step. Then Save.

  4. Create Role Mappings
    1. Click to enter the Identity Provider just created. Navigate to ‚ÄúRole Collection Mappings‚Äù





    2. Create New Rolle Collection Mapping to map the Role Collection to the Groups create in SAP Cloud Identity Service in Section 3 - Step 1.





      For other Groups, the Role Collection Mappings are as below:



  5. Download SAP HANA Cockpit metadata.
    1. Go back to ‚ÄúSecurity‚Äù ‚Äì ‚ÄúIdP Trust Configuration‚Äù, click ‚ÄúShow UAA trust metadata‚Äù



    2. Copy and paste the content to local and save as .xml, E.g. Cockpit_Metadata.xml

There‚Äôs another way to download the SAP HANA Cockpit metadata, which is to open below URL directly in web browser.
https://<fqdn>:3<instance number>32/uaa-security/saml/metadata

Section 5. Configuration in SAP Cloud Identity Service Part III ‚Äì IdP setup

  1. Create Application for SAP HANA Cockpit in SAP IDS
    1. Open the Identity Provider service, access ‚ÄúApplications & Resources‚Äù ‚Äì Applications



    2. Create your Application for SAP HANA Cockpit



    3. In the Application, click ‚ÄúSAML 2.0 Configuration‚Äù under Trust tab ‚Äì Single Sign-On section



    4. Import the metadata of SAP HANA Cockpit
      Click ‚ÄúUpload Metadata‚Äù



    5. Select the metadata .xml file, i.e. Cockpit_Metadata.xml downloaded in Section 4 - Step 5. Download SAP HANA Cockpit Metadata, and ‚ÄúUpload‚Äù. No need to maintain the Endpoints.



  2. Configure the Subject Name Identifier
    1. Go back to the Application created for SAP HANA Cockpit, click to enter ‚ÄúSubject Name Identifier‚Äù under Trust tab ‚Äì Single Sign-On section.



    2. Set the Primary Attribute as
      Source: Identity Directory
      Value: Email



  3. Configure IdP Attributes
    1. Go back to the Application for SAP HANA Cockpit, click to enter ‚ÄúAttributes‚Äù.



    2. Add Attribute - Groups
      Name: Groups
      Source: select ‚ÄúIdentity Directory‚Äù
      Value: select ‚ÄúAll Groups‚Äù from the drop-down list



    3. Add Attribute - ResourceGroups
      Name: ResourceGroups
      Source: select ‚ÄúExpression‚Äù
      Value: enter ‚Äú${customAttribute1}‚Äù

    4. Add Attribute - Resources
      Name: Resources
      Source: select ‚ÄúExpression‚Äù
      Value: enter ‚Äú${customAttribute2}‚Äù

      Then ‚ÄúSave‚Äù.

Now all configuration is done, you can test the SAML SSO by launching SAP HANA Cockpit and single sign-on with IdP. Then the mapped database group is shown on top of other tiles.

entry.title: Is there an API for MIRO Posting in SAP S/4HANA Cloud (Public Edition 2508)?
entry.content:
We are currently using an RPA process for AP invoice postings (MIRO equivalent) in SAP S/4HANA Cloud, Public Edition 2508. The RPA solution takes approximately 1 hour for 35 invoices, mainly due to connectivity and navigation overhead.

To improve efficiency, we would like to know:

  • Is there a standard API available in SAP S/4HANA Cloud that supports MIRO-equivalent posting (Supplier Invoice creation with PO reference)?

  • Can we leverage the API_SUPPLIERINVOICE_PROCESS_SRV OData service for this purpose?

  • Are there any specific restrictions or configuration steps required in the Public Cloud edition to enable supplier invoice posting via API?

Any guidance, official documentation links, or best practices would be highly appreciated.

For public cloud system, currently there is no available configuration activity to set the default document type when creating supplier invoice.

entry.title: Risk Management in SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:

Introduction

With the new Risks feature, SAP Cloud ALM expands its Application Lifecycle Management portfolio. Risks can now be:

‚úÖidentified ‚úÖ assessed ‚úÖ monitored

directly within the tool, allowing project teams to maintain an overview of potential challenges at all times and take countermeasures early on.

üëâMore transparency. üëâ Better decisions. üëâ Greater project security.

Another step toward making SAP implementation and further development even more successful.

#SAP #CloudALM #SAPCloudALM #RiskManagement #Innovation #ProjectSuccess #Risks ProjectManagement

How to work with Risks in SAP Cloud ALM

Find and display the new "Risks" tile in the App Finder.

Click the "+" icon and add the new Risks tile to the home screen.

Create a new Risk

New risks can now be identified.

The Result

A risk list with the assessed risks, which can then be monitored.

entry.title: Re: SAP Datasphere - Architecture and Lessons-Learned
entry.content:
Thanks for sharing your experience, and for the very neat blog!
What I like spaces for, especially segregating them by SAP modules, when it's the primary Source System in a 2-3 tier landscape:
> They force developers to think where to put the objects and who takes the ownership.
> The lineage visibility is much more clear.
> They force developers to analyse dependencies between transport packages and communicate.
> Segregation of storage, compute, connections.
> Service approach, isolation, authorizations.
What I don't like:
< Not being able to easily join cross-space views from the Database Explorer.
< Maintenance. 

I have some thoughts about putting Fact Views in the reporting layer and not propagation too, but that maybe for another time.

Cheers!

entry.title: Re: Support for Base64-Encoded Fingerprints in SFTP Adapter
entry.content:
@CCSAPCEPSA 

If you are on SP33 Patch 0 or Patch 1, you must configure the fingerprint in Base64 format (e.g., SHA256:xxxxxx‚Ä¶) for the scenario to work, since the server provides the fingerprint in this format. However, any existing scenarios with fingerprints configured in hexadecimal format will fail during fingerprint validation.

The enhancement described in SAP Note 3652688 is available starting from SP33 Patch 2. With this change, fingerprints configured in hexadecimal format (with or without MD5/SHA1 prefix) will work without issues. If you want to use Base64 format fingerprints, you must explicitly configure them in the channel and set the parameter useBase64Fingerprint to true.

entry.title: Re: Use case of MMRV
entry.content:
Hello @KARTHIK-G 

That's right - MMRV switches on/off postings to a previous period:

A typical business case of such backpostings is that not all MM postings are entered into the system in real time. For instance receipts from production may be posted in real time, they might be automatically posted by a MES system. Therefore production needs a new period opened at the very beginning of a month. However other postings might be entered with a delay, for instance office supplies receipts might be posted only during working days, not on weekends.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: Re: S4HC Public Cloud Eclipse created CDS and AMDP
entry.content:
I have now got this working.  The error that I first received was a Red Herring ü¶ê  - it led me down a rabbit hole üê∞ that I did not need to enter.üò´  It said The client handling annotation was wrong...   well that was only part of the problem. ‚õ≥

In S/4HANA Public Cloud there are restrictions - mainly on that Blog example I found (I now know it is only suits on-premise - a very important point) it is that ACDOCA is not a table that can be selected directly in public cloud at least- another related CDS in S/4 is to be found - I used I_JournalEntryItem.  At least in my version it is also quite particular about client/mandt, declarations of parameter types, database function select of data using the parameters,API state contracts.

Here is what I did

Define view entity ZVE_JournalData - and this has the API State Contract C1: Use System-Internally set.

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'CDS ViewEntityon I_JOURNALENTRYITEMCUBE'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define view entity ZVE_JournalData 
  with parameters

    p_bukrs : abap.char(4), //MAYBE ALSO DO NOT USE TYPE BUKRS here either - as class method gets error SQLSCRIPT message: invalid identifier: parameterized sql view ZVE_JOURNALDATA without input arguments

    p_gjahr : abap.char(4) //MAYBE ALSO DO NOT USE TYPE gjahr here either
    
as select from I_JournalEntryItem as J
{

  J.Ledger              as RLDNR,

  J.CompanyCode         as RBUKRS,

  J.FiscalYear          as GJAHR,

  J.AccountingDocument  as BELNR    
}
where

  J.CompanyCode = $parameters.p_bukrs

  and J.FiscalYear = $parameters.p_gjahr;

Define table function Z_JOURNAL_DATA

@EndUserText.label: 'Journal Data'


@ClientHandling.algorithm: #SESSION_VARIABLE //the client_element_name column is filled from the session client (sy-mandt).
@ClientHandling.type: #CLIENT_DEPENDENT
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED // No auth checks (default)

define table function Z_JOURNAL_DATA
with parameters 
     i_RBUKRS  : abap.char( 4 ), //do not use type BUKRS as class gets error The object DTEL BUKRS must not be used here, because it is not released for usage in AMDP methods.
     i_GJAHR   : abap.char(4) ////do not use type GJAHR as class gets error The object DTEL GJAHR must not be used here, because it is not released for usage in AMDP methods.
    
returns {
    rclnt :mandt; //Z_JOURNAL_DATA is marked as client-specific so this is NEEDED 
    
    RLDNR : fins_ledger; 
    RBUKRS: bukrs; 
    GJAHR : gjahr; 
    BELNR : belnr_d; 
  
}

implemented by method zcl_acc_je_dat=>GET_JE_DATA;

Define the AMDP Class zcl_acc_je_dat METHOD GET_JE_DATA BY DATABASE FUNCTION

I am not entirely happy with the SELECT returning that CLIENT but was the only way I could get it to work.

CLASS zcl_acc_je_dat DEFINITION PUBLIC.
PUBLIC SECTION.

INTERFACES if_amdp_marker_hdb.
    CLASS-METHODS  GET_JE_DATA
 FOR TABLE FUNCTION Z_JOURNAL_DATA.

ENDCLASS.

CLASS zcl_acc_je_dat IMPLEMENTATION.
METHOD GET_JE_DATA BY DATABASE FUNCTION FOR HDB LANGUAGE SQLSCRIPT OPTIONS READ-ONLY USING ZVE_JOURNALDATA.

RETURN SELECT
                  SESSION_CONTEXT('CLIENT') as rclnt,
                  rldnr,
                  rbukrs,
                  gjahr,
                  belnr
           FROM ZVE_JOURNALDATA( p_bukrs => :i_rbukrs, p_gjahr => :i_gjahr );

ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

The data can be previewed in Eclipse when I connect to my data client 100 (objects developed in my dev client 080)

 

I also wanted to create in my S/4 public cloud application üè¢ a Custom CDS View

For that I have also a define view entity ZVE_Z_JOURNAL_DATA.  This also needed the API State System-Internally contract C1 set

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'CDS View on TableFunction.For S4 CustCDS'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define view entity ZVE_Z_JOURNAL_DATA
  with parameters
    p_bukrs : bukrs,
    p_gjahr : gjahr

  as select from Z_JOURNAL_DATA (
                     i_RBUKRS: $parameters.p_bukrs,
                     i_GJAHR : $parameters.p_gjahr
                   ) as d
{
  key d.BELNR,
      d.RLDNR,
      d.RBUKRS,
      d.GJAHR

}

and so my S/4 application the Custom CDS View was created on that view entity.  Seen displayed here with the parameters entered

"Canada" : [key: "CA", currency: "CAD"], "Germany" : [key: "DE", currency: "EUR"], "United Kingdom": [key: "GB", currency: "GBP"] ] // Retrieve orgs def matchedOrgs = message.getProperty("SapAddressList") ?: [] // Process missing addresses from incoming XML if (!missingAddresses.isEmpty()) { def aggregatorBody = message.getBody(String) if (aggregatorBody) { def xml = new XmlSlurper().parseText(aggregatorBody) aggregatedAddresses = xml.AddressResponse.collect { addr -> [ ID : addr.ID.text(), address : addr.address.text(), street : addr.street.text(), number : addr.houseNumber.text(), city : addr.city.text(), country : addr.country.text(), countryKey_code: addr.countryKeyCode.text() ] } } } // Merge SAP + newly created addresses (unique by ID) def allAddresses = (sapAddressList + aggregatedAddresses).unique { it.ID } message.setProperty("AggregatedAddresses", aggregatedAddresses) message.setProperty("AllAddresses", allAddresses) // Combine matched and missing orgs into allOrgs def allOrgs = [] // Add matched orgs matchedOrgs.each { org -> allOrgs << [ Name : org.Name ?: "", Street : org.Street ?: "", Number : org.Number ?: "", City : org.City ?: "", Country : org.Country ?: "", addressID_ID : org.addressID_ID ?: "", address : org.address ?: "${org.Street ?: ""} ${org.City ?: ""} ${org.Country ?: ""} ${org.Number ?: ""}".trim() ] } // Add missing addresses missingAddresses.each { org -> def addr = aggregatedAddresses.find { it.street.equalsIgnoreCase(org.Street ?: "") && it.city.equalsIgnoreCase(org.City ?: "") && it.country.equalsIgnoreCase(org.Country ?: "") && ((it.number ?: "") == (org.Number ?: "")) } allOrgs << [ Name : org.Name ?: "", Street : org.Street ?: "", Number : org.Number ?: "", City : org.City ?: "", Country : org.Country ?: "", addressID_ID : addr?.ID ?: "", address : addr?.address ?: "${org.Street ?: ""} ${org.City ?: ""} ${org.Country ?: ""} ${org.Number ?: ""}".trim(), countryKey_code: addr?.countryKey_code ?: "" ] } // Generate unique 4-character company codes def usedCodes = [:].withDefault { 0 } def writer = new StringWriter() def xmlBuilder = new MarkupBuilder(writer) def correlationId = java.util.UUID.randomUUID().toString() message.setProperty("ammsOrgId", correlationId) message.setProperty("expectedCompanyCodeCount", allOrgs.size()) xmlBuilder.Organisations { allOrgs.each { org -> // Clean organization name def cleanName = (org.Name ?: "ORG").replaceAll("\\s","").toUpperCase() def baseCode = cleanName.take(4) // Ensure unique code def count = usedCodes[baseCode] def companyCode = count == 0 ? baseCode : baseCode.take(Math.max(0, 4 - count.toString().length())) + count.toString() usedCodes[baseCode] = count + 1 // Country & currency info def countryInfo = countryMap[org.Country] ?: [key: "", currency: "EUR"] // Build Organisation node safely using mkp.yield Organisation(ammsOrgId: correlationId) { companyCode { mkp.yield companyCode } companyCodeName { mkp.yield (org.Name ?: "") } countryKey_code { mkp.yield (org.countryKey_code ?: countryInfo.key) } currency_code { mkp.yield countryInfo.currency } addressID_ID { mkp.yield (org.addressID_ID ?: "") } address { mkp.yield (org.address ?: "${org.Street ?: ""} ${org.City ?: ""} ${org.Country ?: ""} ${org.Number ?: ""}".trim()) } } } } message.setBody(writer.toString()) // Logging def log = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message) if (log) { log.addAttachmentAsString("SAP_Addresses", sapAddressList.toString(), "application/json") log.addAttachmentAsString("NewlyCreated_Addresses", aggregatedAddresses.toString(), "application/json") log.addAttachmentAsString("AllAddresses", allAddresses.toString(), "application/json") log.addAttachmentAsString("Org_XML_for_Splitter", writer.toString(), "application/xml") log.addAttachmentAsString("AMMS_ammsOrgId", correlationId.toString(), "text/plain") log.addAttachmentAsString("expectedCompanyCodeCount", allOrgs.size().toString(), "text/plain") } return message }

entry.title: Duration Replication for Professional Services Project between S4HC and RM
entry.content:
Here are the documents we have to explain how duration replication works for Project Services Projects:

  1. Help document: Delta Replication for Professional Services Projects
  2. KBA: 3603920 - Resource request period remains unchanged after extending the project period in S4HC.

Despite these documents, several customers have raised questions about this functionality. To address this, I ran tests in my internal system and compiled the behaviors with sample scenarios. I hope this provides a clearer understanding.

Scenario 1: When extending the duration, the changes will not be reflected in RM.

Example:

Initial work package  time period: 01.09.2025-30.09.2025
Resource request time period: 01.09.2025-30.09.2025

New work package time period: 18.08.2025-17.10.2025
New resource request time period: 01.09.2025-30.09.2025

Scenario 2: When the duration is shortened, the changes will be reflected in RM.

Example:

Initial work package  time period: 01.08.2025-30.09.2025
Resource request time period: 01.08.2025-30.09.2025

New work package time period: 15.08.2025-15.09.2025
New resource request time period: 15.08.2025-15.09.2025

Scenario 3: When the new duration lies entirely outside the previous duration, the changes will be reflected in RM.

Example:

Initial work package  time period: 01.09.2025-30.09.2025
Resource request time period: 01.09.2025-30.09.2025

New work package time period: 25.08.2025-31.08.2025
New resource request time period: 25.08.2025-31.08.2025

Scenario 4: When the new duration overlaps with the previous duration, the overlapping time will be updated in in RM.

Example:

Initial work package  time period: 01.08.2025-30.08.2025
Resource request time period: 01.08.2025-30.08.2025

New work package time period: 26.08.2025-22.09.2025
New resource request time period: 26.08.2025-30.08.2025

entry.title: Re: ECC6 upgrade operating system and database
entry.content:
Hi,

Whether a specific Microsoft Windows Server OS version can be 'in-place' upgraded to an higher OS version is and issue which depends on Microsoft guidelines.
OS 'in-place' upgrade is not valid for all Microsoft OS versions, so I recommend you ask your Microsoft OS partner whether the 'Microsoft OS in-place' upgrade method is valid for achieving OS upgrade from Windows Server OS 2012/2012R2 to 2019 or 2022 versions or not.

For more information see the Microsoft documentation below:

https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-server/get-started/upgrade-overview

Regards,
Riccardo

entry.title: Workforce Management in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2508
entry.content:
Welcome to your one-stop shop to learn and share knowledge about SAP¬¥s ready-to-run public Cloud ERP software solution. SAP S/4HANS Cloud Public Edition is part of SAP Business Suite that brings AI, data and applications together into a fully integrated system. This community is open for anyone in the Cloud ERP ecosystem ‚Äì customers, partners, and SAP experts.  

Managing a skilled workforce efficiently is paramount for any growing organization. With the release 2508 of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, businesses are empowered with robust HR connectivity options, which streamline workforce management activities. This article provides guidance on handling workforce data, work agreements, and user management using various technical integration options.

In traditional Identity Management (IDM) scenarios, HR systems usually take the lead in managing worker data and work agreements. Business user data might be managed directly in an IDM system or integrated via an HR system. The culmination of these processes sees the provisioning of worker data, work agreements, and business user data into the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition tenant through effective HR and IDM integration. Successful workforce management in this landscape hinges on strategic decisions about data creation through HR or IDM integration, based on which system leads.

 

Results: Realizing Workforce Management Scenarios


Imagine a scenario where SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition is integrated with both the SAP SuccessFactors Employee Central (using SAP Master Data Integration for HR) and an external IDM system via SOAP-based integration with SAP Cloud Identity Services. Here, aligning IDM integration as the leading choice brings forth several advantages.

 

Define Workforce Management System and Choose an Integration Option

  • IDM Integration Leads: Creating business user and worker data first allows users to access the system and perform tasks without needing pre-established work agreements.
  • HR Integration Leads: Worker data and work agreements are provisioned first, followed by business user creation, ensuring structured data flow.

To configure your scenario, access SAP Central Business Configuration for your specific tenant, locate the Define Workforce Management Scenario (106757) activity, and select your desired option: IDM or HR integration. Be sure to confirm data consistency across systems before switching options.

 

Flexible Data Management

With the integration setup, you can create worker and business user data within SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition through the integration with SAP Cloud Identity Services or manually via the Manage Workforce or Maintain Business Users apps. However, once data is created through integration, it cannot be modified directly in these apps. The Entry Source field denotes where data can be edited and its origin. Refer to the Entry Source documentation for further information. If establishing a work agreement through HR integration precedes the creation of a worker record, an error will occur.

SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition empowers businesses with flexible HR connectivity options for workforce management. By carefully selecting and implementing integration strategies, organizations can achieve efficient operations and seamless data management, essential for navigating the complex terrain of modern business environments. Choose the path that aligns best with your operational needs, ensuring a smooth and effective workforce management experience.

entry.title: How does the official start date impact employee benefits calculation?
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I‚Äôve been researching how to properly calculate end-of-service benefits, particularly in scenarios where there‚Äôs a contract signing date and a visa-stamping / work-permit activation date.

Contract signed: Jan 2018 Visa stamped / legal work authorization: March 2018 Last working day: Feb 2021 My question: Which date should generally be used as the ‚Äúofficial start date‚Äù for benefits/gratuity calculations under UAE law the contract signing or visa stamping?

I know in some jurisdictions only the visa/permit date matters; but are there SAP customers/implementers who have encountered payroll configurations or HR modules where contract date was used (if support documents exist)?

For those who might want to check or confirm, I found this online tool helpful:https://calculategratuity.ae/ it takes start date, contract type, end date and calculates gratuity according to UAE labour law. Might be useful to compare values.

entry.title: Re: Difference between TYPE and LIKE in ABAP ‚Äì When to us...
entry.content:
Just for your information: If you are new to SAP ABAP or the SAP ecosystem, it is highly recommended to first refer to the official SAP documentation: SAP ABAP Documentation. Before posting questions, please also try searching on Google, the SAP Community, or even tools like ChatGPT, as many answers are already available. This helps you learn faster and ensures questions are more focused.

However, please answer below.

1.  TYPE 

Declare a variable based on a data type (built-in or DDIC type). 

Syntax:

DATA var TYPE abap_type [LENGTH len] [DECIMALS dec] [VALUE val] [READ-ONLY].

Eg:

 

DATA text TYPE string VALUE 'Text'.
DATA count TYPE i VALUE 1.
DATA price TYPE p LENGTH 8 DECIMALS 2 VALUE '1.99'.

2 LIKE  

Declare a variable based on another variable or table/field.

  • LIKE copies the type and attributes of another variable or data object.

  • Useful to create new variables similar to existing ones.

Syntax:

 

DATA var LIKE existing_var_or_field [VALUE val] [READ-ONLY].

Eg:

DATA wa TYPE scarr. " Work area based on DDIC table SCARR
SELECT SINGLE * FROM scarr INTO @wa WHERE carrid = 'BA'.
DATA buffer LIKE wa. " Another variable with same type as wa buffer = wa.

Comparison 

Feature TYPE LIKE
Refers toType definition (DDIC or ABAP)Existing variable/field
Updates if DDIC changesYesOnly if referencing the field
Recommended forIn most cases, future-proofCopying existing variables
ExampleDATA lv_value TYPE i.DATA lv_temp LIKE lv_value.

Note:

Always use TYPE for work areas of tables (from DDIC)

Try to avoid LIKE as much as possible 

Eg:

DATA gt_scarr TYPE TABLE OF scarr. " Correct
DATA wa_scarr LIKE LINE OF gt_scarr. " Work area based on table

entry.title: Data Migration for Test Environment Validation in 3-system‚ÄØlandscape.
entry.content:
Embarking on the 3-System Landscape (SL) journey in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition can be overwhelming. A newly provisioned test tenant may not operate efficiently unless it contains sufficient known data to support you best with testing and validations. 

To address this challenge and accelerate test tenant readiness, SAP has introduced two strategic options, namely TEST DATA CONVERSION and TEST DATA REFRESH. These features are designed to accelerate tenant readiness by simplify data handling and thereby enhancing overall system efficiency. 

In this blog, we‚Äôll take a high-level look at the 3-SL and explore how TEST DATA CONVERSION and TEST DATA REFRESH facilitate to a smoother, faster, and reliable test environment setup. 

 

3-SL  

As part of your strategic transformation, you are planning to migrate from a 2-SL to a 3-SL in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. This transition is aimed at enhancing system governance, improving testing capabilities, and enabling a clear change management process. Before diving into the data migration services, let‚Äôs examine the landscape differences between the current 2-SL setup and the target 3-SL setup to understand the value and impact of this shift.  

 As part of the 3-SL conversion in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, a new test tenant is introduced to support robust validation and quality assurance. However, at the time of conversion, this tenant is provisioned as an empty tenant, with no data (transactional or master data) available. To make this test tenant fully functional and efficient, it must be filled with the essential fuel that drives all meaningful testing, which is nothing but valid data. 

As the saying goes, ‚ÄúData is the new fuel‚Äù and without it, even the most advanced SL cannot deliver value to its fullest. Populating the test tenant with relevant, valid, and consistent data is critical to make the test tenant valuable and ensure a smooth transition to production tenants. 

Now that we understand the importance of data in powering the test tenant, the next step is to determine how to introduce this data effectively into test tenants.

 

Manual Data Uploads: A Time-Consuming Process 

While manual data uploads are technically possible using SAP Fiori apps, templates, or others. but they involve significant drawbacks: 

  • High Effort: Manually preparing valid data and uploading data comes at the cost of extensive time and resources.  
  • Cumbersome Process: This process itself will be complex and challenging as multiple tools and formats need to be used and the complexity increases with large data volumes. 
  • Delayed Availability: Test tenant will not be available for business use until the manual data upload is completed, there by blocking the testing activities for the released objects.

We have seen that, manual data entry is not ideal for large volume of data upload and accelerating tenant readiness. 

 

Embracing Automation: Smarter Ways to Populate Your Test Tenant 

We‚Äôre in the era of automation and manual data entry is no longer a viable option for efficient system setup. If you already have rich, validated data in your customizing tenant and production tenant, the question becomes: 
How can you use this data to build a clean, depersonalized, and test-ready environment in your new test tenant. To address this common pain point, SAP has introduced two specialized services designed to simplify and accelerate the process: 

  • TEST DATA CONVERSION ‚Äì post-conversion accelerator 
  • TEST DATA REFRESH ‚Äì Ongoing quality assurance 

 

To streamline the setup of a new test tenant, SAP offers two powerful services that cater to different data sources and testing needs: 

 TEST DATA CONVERSION Service ‚Äì post-conversion accelerator 

  • Purpose: Transfers configuration and application data from the Customizing Tenant to the New Test Tenant. 
  • Goal: Ensures the new test system is available seamlessly and without issues, reflecting the latest customizing setup. 
  • Source System: Customizing Tenant 
  • Target System: New Test Tenant 

This service is ideal for scenarios where you want to validate configurations, execute test cases, test new features based on your previous customizing tenant. 

 

 TEST DATA REFRESH Service ‚Äì Ongoing quality assurance 

  • Purpose: Transfers selected business data from the Production Tenant to the New Test Tenant. 
  • Goal: Ensures the new test system is populated with production-like test data, enabling realistic testing and ongoing quality assurance. 
  • Source System: Production Tenant 
  • Target System: New Test Tenant 

This service is perfect for regression testing, integration validation, and performance benchmarking using real-world data.

 

What‚Äôs Next? 

In this blog, we explored the two key services TEST DATA CONVERSION and TEST DATA REFRESH that help populate a new test tenant efficiently. We also clarified the source and target systems for each service along with their roles in test tenant setup. 

In the next blog, we‚Äôll take a deep dive into the TEST DATA CONVERSION service, examining its capabilities, process flow, and how it ensures a seamless transition from the customizing tenant to the test tenant. Stay tuned to uncover configuration tips, and real-world use cases that make TEST DATA CONVERSION a game-changer for test system readiness. 

 

Reference links: 

Blogs:
  • 3SL Conversion for two-system landscape customers managed by SAP Central Business Configuration
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud 3SL onboarding and initial system set-up series
  • Streamlining 3SL Post Conversion Steps: Introducing CIAS and TDC Services
  • https://community.sap.com/t5/technology-blog-posts-by-sap/test-data-refresh-service-request-on-sap-for-me/ba-p/14171893

Community Pages:

  • https://pages.community.sap.com/topics/s4hana-cloud/three-system-landscape

entry.title: Re: ROLE AUTHORIZATION PFCG
entry.content: One of the roles assigned to USER1 has authorisation object S_TABU_DIS with wide display rights. SE16 can be restricted by table (S_TABU_NAM), but also by table authorisation group (S_TABU_DIS). The check order is that if S_TABU_DIS fails, only then is S_TABU_NAM checked. S_TABU_DIS with * is a critical authorisation based on the SAP Security Baseline Template.

entry.title: Synchronizing ERP Vendor IDs and SM IDs Between SAP Ariba and Multiple ERPs
entry.content:
Dear SAP Community,

I am currently working on an integration scenario involving SAP Ariba Supplier Management and multiple SAP ERPs via CIG (Cloud Integration Gateway), and I would like to get your expert input on the best approach to fulfill a specific client requirement.

Context and Requirement:
The customer wants to ensure that new suppliers are always created starting from SAP Ariba Network. Once a supplier is registered and qualified in Ariba, the goal is to maintain a single ERP Vendor ID and one SM ID across the landscape.

The main objectives are:

  • Avoiding double maintenance of suppliers across systems.
  • Ensuring a consistent relationship between one SM ID in Ariba and one ERP Vendor ID in the connected ERP systems.
  • Preventing a scenario where one supplier in Ariba has one SM ID but two different ERP Vendor IDs (which, to my knowledge, is not supported).

Possible Approach Considered:

  • Supplier is created in Ariba with an SM ID.
  • A temporary vendor ID (e.g., VDRxxx) is generated and routed via CIG to both ERPs.
  • At the registration approval stage, the integration to ERP 1 provides the final ERP Vendor ID.
  • The open question: Can this final ERP Vendor ID also be pushed automatically to ERP 2 via CIG so that both ERPs share the same vendor ID for the supplier?

One possible design that comes to mind would be to allow the supplier to be initially created in Ariba with its SM ID and a temporary vendor ID, for example VDRxxx. In this initial phase, the information could be routed via CIG to both ERPs. The point of uncertainty arises when the supplier reaches the stage of registration approval: if the first ERP integration returns a final ERP Vendor ID, could this same vendor ID then be pushed and synchronized also to the second ERP? In other words, is there a standard mechanism within CIG and Ariba Supplier Management to enforce the use of a single ERP Vendor ID across multiple ERPs, or would this require a different design approach?

Final Questions:

  1. Is the above scenario feasible with standard Ariba‚ÄìCIG capabilities?
  2. If not, what would be the recommended best practice to ensure alignment between ERP Vendor IDs and SM IDs across multiple ERPs?
  3. Considering an architecture of 1 parent and 1 child (buying and invoicing), what is the most reliable approach to avoid duplicate supplier maintenance while maintaining consistent identifiers?

Thank you for your help and support!

entry.title: Re: How many licenses needed for SAP Adaptive Enterprise...
entry.content:
Hello Sergio

The number of licenses required would be 32. 

Please refer to https://support.sap.com/en/my-support/keys/license-key-help.html

(I had an issue with this direct link which may have to do with SAP Portal, if so use navigation
On SAP Portal, go to 'Keys' tile
Then expand Licene Key help (click on > before it)
Link to 'License Key help'
Use 'SAP Sybase' tab
There is an FAQ 'What is number of licenses'

The number of licenses to be specified depends on how many licensed units are needed for the application running on this machine. For entitlements licensed under CPU license types, the quantity should correspond to the number of processors, i.e. cores, on the machine, partition or resource-set.

Support KBA also covers this:
https://me.sap.com/notes/3143614 SYSAM core licenses requirement when hyper-threading is enabled - SAP ASE

Kind regards

Bart

entry.title: Re: ABAP SALV Table with Checkbox Column, Select/Deselect All, and Email Export Functionality
entry.content:
Why did you code the selection yourself instead of using the standard one?

gr_table->get_selections( )->set_selection_mode( cl_salv_selections=>multiple ).

Using IF_SALV_C_SELECTION_MODE~MULTIPLE for modern selection of lines (click anywhere in the table) and IF_SALV_C_SELECTION_MODE~ROW_COLUMN for classical selection of lines (with checkboxes)
